greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Let f denote the map that replaces k with the concatenation of its proper divisors, written in decreasing order, each divisor being written in base 10 with its digits in reverse order. Then a(n) = first prime reached when starting at 2n+1 and iterating f.
comment: If 2n+1 is 1 or a prime, set a(n) = 2n+1. If no prime is ever reached, set a(n) = -1.
example: n = 13: 2n+1 = 27 has proper divisors 3 and 9, so we get 93, which has proper divisors 3 and 31, so we get 133.
Then 133 has proper divisors 7 and 19, so we get 917.
Then 917 has proper divisors 7 and 131, so we get 1317.
Then 1317 has proper divisors 3 and 439, so we get 9343, a prime and a(13) = 9343.
Proof chain for a(17). The following gives the argument to f at each step, followed by its factorization.
765...4892 (3249 digits) is divisible by 2, and hence all subsequent steps will be divisible by 2, therefore no prime is ever reached, therefore a(17)=-1. (End)
results.author: Adam L. Buchsbaum (alb(AT)research.att.com), Jul 30 2007, Aug 01 2007
ext: The value of a(17) is currently unknown.
5 more terms (details for a(17) in example). Next term requires factoring a 1478-digit number. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Sep 11 2009
